The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Ata Ilahi Sher Mohammad Group

texts.en:
Ata ilahi baji has been a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan for the past ten years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Her husband’s name is S. M. and he runs a bicycle-rental business. He has been in this business for the past four years.

Ata baji runs a clothes-sewing business. She is a very jovial by nature. She tries to make everyone happy by her good behavior. She is applying for a loan to buy another bicycle to expand her husband’s bicycle-rental business. 

Ata baji is the group leader of two other women from her locality:

Sajida parveen baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

Rasheeda baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading.

loans.use: To buy another bicycle for her husband's bicycle-rental business

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort sells provisions. She hopes for the loan of N100,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. Comfort is 60 years old and married with six children. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Gora

texts.fr: Gora est un chauffeur de taxi  urbain .Chaque jour il fait le tour de ville de Mbour à la rechercher de clients .Les revenus tirés du transport lui permettent d’entretenir sa femme et ses enfants mais ses parents. Avec le prêt  obtenu il  veut acheter un autre moteur pour son taxi a fin de ne pas rester au chaumage. À  trente six ans (36) ans son projet avec l IMCEC  est d’acheter un autre véhicule pour renforcer son  parc auto et renforcer ses revenus.
texts.en:
Gora is an urban taxi driver. Each day, he goes throughout the city of Mbour looking for customers. The income derived from transportation allows him to care for his wife and children and his parents, too. With the loan in hand, he wants to buy another motor for his taxi in order to stay out of unemployment. At the age of 36, he has a plan with IMCEC to buy another vehicle to enhance his fleet and to bolster his income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motor

loans.name: Azra Khalid Mahmood Group

texts.en:
Azra baji is a very hardworking lady. She prepares embroidered dresses on order which she collects from the cloth markets. She completes the order even if she is ill or tired. Her family is very inspired by her.

Her hardworking quality gives power to her husband also who runs a business selling plastic utensils. He goes to different communities and sells his utensils by making a loud voice. Azra baji is applying for a loan to buy utensils to expand her husband’s business. 

She is the group leader of two other women from her locality:

Naziran baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) for her animal-selling business.

Nargis baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

loans.use: To buy utensils for her husband to sell

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en: Rachael sells building materials. She is 42 years old and married with 3 children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more building materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 47-year-old Grace A. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children, between the ages of 14 and 25. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependants while they are attending school in the area. Grace has been running a women’s shoes and bags business since 2006. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week. Grace currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more shoes and bags. In the future, she plans to open another business. Grace thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags for her business.

loans.name: Maendeleo 'a' Group

texts.en:
Elfrida owns a small shop in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to Maendeleo 'A' group loan (Group code 2014).  Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to add her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to expand her business.  

Elfrida is 41 years old, married, and has five children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Veronica. Veronica has her own small business selling hens and eggs in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more items to add her current stock for her shop.

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Bahati S. from Tukuyu. She is married with one child, age 2. Bahati has been running a business, since 2007, purchasing and selling cereals. She works at her business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by 2 family members. Bahati currently earns about 100USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase cereals in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Bahati thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase cereals in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Murtaza Loan Group

texts.en:
Muniran baji is 30 years old, married and widely known as a very hard-working woman. She runs a business in her house that makes clothing, and has a large number  of customers, including many of her neighbors. Muniran baji’s husband runs a grocery store. People in their community know the couple very well and speak highly of them. Muniran baji is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s shop.

She leads a loan group that has three other members. Saima baji wants a loan to buy supplies -- such as wires, switchboards and switches -- for her electric shop. Kishwar baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Gulzaran baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her store.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to help four small businesses expand

loans.name: Catherin's Group

texts.en: Catherin owns a small general store in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She currently earns about $270 a month, and works for 12 hours a day. She is applying for her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can add to her inventory and increase sales. She hopes that this loan will allow her to increase profits and grow her business.  Catherin is 38 years old, married and has three children, ages 13, 10 and 7.  She will share this loan with her fellow group member, Feda, who owns her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Bayasgalan

texts.en: Bayasgalan D. is 46 years old, divorced and lives with her mother and 16-year-old daughter in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her daughter is a student in the local high school. Bayasgalan runs a small retail business selling food products. She opened his store in 2004 with a small amount of capital, selling fewer than 10 different food items from a small stall at the local market. Today, her business has expanded and more than tripled in value. In the future, she would like to open her own food store where she would be able to supply quality food to residents of her community. She has applied for this loan to buy more products to sell.

loans.use: to buy more food products to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose R. makes a living selling bedsheets and has applied for a loan to open up a shop in a busy market in Konyokonyo, where she expects to have many customers. She has two children, both boys, who go to school. Her husband is a police officer. In the future, she hopes to buy a motor bike to transport clothes to the market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs, as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. Its microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to open up a shop in the local market

loans.name: Razia M.farooq Sultan Group

texts.en:
Razia baji is a wife of M. S., and for the last five years has lived in Borewala, Pakistan, a town that is famous for its shrines. She has two children, one daughter and one son, both enrolled in a local school. Razia baji helps support her family and pay their school fees by making clothing. Her husband is a salesman and sells baked items such as breads to different bakeries. Razia baji is applying for this loan to buy items for her husband to sell so that he can earn a profit. 

She leads a loan group that includes two other women who live in her town. Kosar parveen baji wants a loan to buy flour to sell. Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy items for her business, which sells window shutters.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To help expand three small businesses

loans.name: Shuhuda

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 47-year-old Suhuda F. R. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children between the ages of 17 and 23. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting an orphaned girl.

Shuhuda has been running a craft business since 2004. She is an extremely enterprising woman who has crafted a successful business from selling vinyagos to tourists. A vinyago is a beautiful, hand-crafted statue made from wood by members of the Makonde tribe, who hail from southeastern Tanzania. Woodcarving is an important part of Makonde life, both in ancestor worship and in their own myth of creation. These statues have three main themes: traditional masks, motifs of female ancestor worship and more abstract modern themes.

She works at the business for five to eight hours per day, six days per week. Shuhuda currently earns about 80 from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase additional stock of vinyago. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Shuhuda thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of vinyago

loans.name: Dorjdagva

texts.en:
Dorjdagva S. lives with his wife and three sons in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His oldest son is a university student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and the other two sons are local high school students.

With his wife, Dorjdagva runs a small business bartering clothes. He often drives and visits herder families in the countryside and trades women's and men's clothing in exchange for animals such as sheep and goats. He tries to select clothes and household items that are in the greatest demand. Once he has successfully traded for the animals, he slaughters them and his wife sells them in small pieces at the local market. Sometime he buys animals for cash. In the future, he would like to open a wholesale section at the local market for animals and meat-related products. He requests a loan to purchase animals at cheap prices.

loans.use: To purchase animals

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Bumi M. from Tukuyu. She is married with a child who is 1 year old. Bumi has been running a clothing business since 2005. She purchases and sells clothes, working nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week. Bumi currently earns about $60 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Bumi thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk

loans.name: Omolara

texts.en: Omolara O. is 43 years old and married with 3 children. She sells provisions and drinks. She is requesting for a loan in the amount of NGN60,000 (US$425) to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo A. is 60 years old and married with 4 children. She sells bags of charcoal. She is requesting for a loan in the amount of NGN 60,000 ($US425) to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Horoldamba

texts.en: Horoldamba A. is 34, married, and the father of three sons. All of his sons are attending an elementary school. His family lives in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Horoldamba runs a grocery store at the center province. In 2002, together with his spouse, Azzaya, Horoldamba started to run a food stall at the local market. He began his business with 1 million tugrugs ($1 USD=1400 MNT), which has now increased to 4 million tugrugs (~US$2800.00). A couple of years ago, Horoldamba decided to expand his business and open a grocery store, that is running today. With the profit he bought a pick up truck for his business needs. He requests a loan to buy food products for his business. Horoldamba is a friendly and helpful person.

loans.use: To buy food products for his grocery store.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Mariam L. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with three children, between the ages of 2 and 13. Mariam has been running a drinking water sales business since 2005. Mariam buys drinking water wholesale and sells it retail. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week. Mariam currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase additional stock of drinking water in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Mariam thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of drinking water in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To sell household and basic need goods

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is in the business of selling fruit such as: tomatoes, mangoes, govva etc. She is requesting a loan to open up a shop. She is 37 years old and married. Her husband is a professional primary teacher and has taught for almost five years in Gudele primary school. They have three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. 

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a shop.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Mambo (geretings) from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Christina N. S. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children between the ages of 3 and 13. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting an orphaned girl. Christina has been running a grocery (genge) business since 2004. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof where general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice and dried fish are sold. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her sister-in-law. Christina currently earns about $80 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase fruits in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Christina thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase fruits in bulk for her store

loans.name: Devota Marule

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Devota M. from Mbeya. She is married with two children, aged 8 and 16. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two orphans. Devota has been running a business purchasing and selling oil since 2008. She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week. Devota currently earns about $100 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase oil in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to open new business. Devota thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To sell shoes and handbags

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Ester M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children, ages 1 and 9. Ester has been selling traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women called kanga and vitenge since 2008. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with a wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures and traditions of native African people. She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Ester currently earns about $100 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase stock in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Ester thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Ndipona

texts.en:
Ndipona owns a small cafe in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya but currently earns very little monthly profit. Each day she works at her business for twelve hours. She belongs to Nzovwe X group loan (Group code 2021).

Ndipona is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Ndipona is 30 years old, married, and has three children: ages 13, 10 and 6. She also cares for one additional dependent.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose owns a small shop in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She belongs to Nzovwe X group loan (Group code 2021). Every day she works at her business for twelve hours.

Rose is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to add to her current stock for the improvement of her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Rose is 39 years old, married, and has six children: ages 19, 17, 14, 9, 7 and 4.

loans.use: To buy more items to add to her current stock

loans.name: Eve

texts.en: Eve is 35 years old and married with two children. She sells provisions and is requesting a loan of N50, 000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Dupe

texts.en:
Dupe A. is 32 years old and married with four children. She sells medicines and provisions.

She is requesting a loan of N40,000 to purchase more medicines and provisions to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines and provisions to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To prepare and sell food

loans.name: Devota

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Devota S. from Mbeya. She is married with two children aged 8 and 16. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans.

Devota has been running an kerosine and firewood business since 2008. People use kerosine and firewood for cooking food. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week, currently earning about $100 a month.

Devota is requesting a loan in order to purchase kerosine and firewood in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to open a new business. She thanks you for your support!


ABOUT SELFINA: 
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase kerosine and firewood in bulk for her business

loans.name: 34-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en: Linh T. Thị (216) is a 41-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Linh is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW). While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 34-Nam Ngạn (17.08.34). Linh is married and has three school-aged children. Linh owns and operates a business making and selling food. She cooks soup (cháo: a rice product) to sell in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 1,200,000 VND a month. In 2008, Linh joined FPW to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,626,900 VND from FPW. This previous loan was used to expand her business. Linh is now requesting a new loan of 1,963,500 VND which will be used to expand her business. The loan will be her 2nd loan from FPW. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. Ngô Thị Hoa (226) is a 22-year-old female who is requesting a 1,963,500 VND loan to support her business cooking soup (cháo) to sell. 2. H. Thị Hường (228) is a 44-year-old female who is requesting a 1,963,500 VND loan to support her business buying medicines to resell in the market. 3. N. Thị Mai (215) is a 50-year-old female who is requesting a 1,963,500 VND loan to support her business buying many kinds of drink like Coca-Cola, beer, etc. to sell in her village. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Linh T. Thị (216) là 41 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Linh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 34-Nam Ngạn (17-08-34). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa phương. Linh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Linh kiếm được khoảng 1.200.000 VND. Vào 2008, Linh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Linh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.626.900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 1.963.500 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Ngô Thị Hoa (226) là 22 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 1.963.500 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Cô ấy nấu cháo để bán. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. 2. H. Thị Hường (228) là 44 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 1.963.500 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. Cô mua thuốc tây để bán. 3. N. Thị Mai (215) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 1.963.500 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. Cô ấy mua nươvs giải khát để bán. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.ru: Муродова  Мухаббат – женщина  49  лет,  замужем,  имеет  4-х  детей. На  протяжении  десяти  лет  Мухаббат  занимается  продажей  одеял,  постельного  белья,  полотенец  и  скатертей  на  вещевом  рынке  Спитаменского  района.  С  2003  года  она  является  одной  из  наших  активных  клиентов.  Один  раз  в  месяц  Мухаббат  ездит  за  товаром  в  г. Бишкек  Республики  Кыргизстан.  Её  муж  мастер  строительных  работ.  Вместе  со  своим  старшим  сыном  он  недавно  вернулся  из  Российской  Федерации.  Мухаббат  и  её  семья  мечтают  о  том,  чтобы  открыть  в  центре  района  свой  собственный  магазин.
texts.en:
Muhabbat M. is a 49-year-old woman, who is married and has four children. For ten years, Muhabbat has sold blankets, bedding, towels and tablecloths at the Spitamen district clothing market. Since 2003, she has been one of MicroInvest's vital customers. Once a month, Muhabbat goes to Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, on a buying trip. Her husband works in construction, and he and their eldest son recently returned from Russia. Muhabbat and her family dream of opening their own shop in the center of the district.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand selection

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To enlarge her store and raise her sales volume

loans.name: Edina Katyega

texts.en: Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 47-year-old Edina K. from Mbeya. She is married with three children between the ages of 14 and 24. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent who is an orphan. Edina has been running a crops business since 1996, purchasing and selling crops. She works at the business for 9 -12 hours per day, six days per week, currently earning about $80 a month. Edina is requesting a loan in order to purchase crops in bulk. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Edina thanks you for your support! ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Ahmajon

texts.ru: Гафуров  Ахмаджон – молодой  человек  28  лет,  женат,  имеет  2-х  детей. Вместе  со  своей  женой  на  продовольственном  рынке  Спитаменского  района он  продаёт  хозяйственные  товары  и  фарфоровую  посуду.  Один  раз  в  неделю  он  ездит  за  товаром  в  г. Худжанд  и  в  Республику  Узбекистан.  Недавно  родители  Ахмаджона  построили  ему  новый  дом,  поэтому  для  расширения  своего  товарооборота  он  обратился  в  нашу  организацию  за  кредитом.  На  заработанные  деньги  Ахмаджон  и  его  семья  собираются  купить  мебель  для  своего  нового  дома.  Ахмаджон  очень  рад  сотрудничеству  с  нами  и  благодарен  нашим  кредиторам  за  помощь  в  осуществлении  его  планов.
texts.en:
Ahmajon G. is a young man of 28, married and has two children. He and his wife sell household goods and chinaware at the Spitamen district food market. Once a week, Ahmajon goes to Khujand and to Uzbekistan on a buying trip. Recently his parents built him a new house, and in order to expand the selection of goods he carries, Ahmajon came to MicroInvest for a loan. With the money he earns, Ahmajon and his family plan to buy furniture for their new home. Ahmajon is pleased to collaborate with MicroInvest and grateful for the loan assistance to bring his plans to fruition.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory expansion

loans.name: Cheikh

texts.fr: Monsieur Cheikh G. sollicite un crédit auprès de l’IMCEC et Kiva pour peindre l’intérieur de sa maison.  Il a déjà fait beaucoup de travaux de réfection chez lui, mais il n’a jamais sollicité un prêt.  Avec ce crédit il va acheter la peinture – il n’a pas encore choisi la couleur, mais il dit que c’est à sa femme de décider.  Il a déjà fini les réfections dans une pièce de sa maison, et il envisage d’utiliser cette pièce pour ouvrir un petit cyber café pour les jeunes dans le quartier.  Monsieur G. est un hôtelier qui gère un hôtel à Mbour, une ville située à 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale du Sénégal.  Il va utiliser les revenus de son hôtel pour rembourser ce prêt.
texts.en:
Mr. Cheikh G. is seeking a loan through IMCEC and Kiva to paint the inside of his house. He has already done a large number of repairs, but he has never sought a loan. With this loan, he will buy paint - he has not yet chosen the colour, but he says the decision is up to his wife. He has already finished the repairs in one room of his house, and he intends to use this room to open a small internet cafe for the youth in his area. Mr. G. is a hotelier who manages a hotel in Mbour, a city located 70 kilometres from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. He will use the income from his hotel to repay this loan.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To paint his house

loans.name: Christine's Group

texts.en:
For N. Christine, joining her lending group of Gakuweebwa munno is the wisest thing she has ever done for her family and business. The reason being, she has been able to expand the stock of her new clothes, her children are attending good schools plus she is able to buy more household items hence improving the standard of living for herself and family.

Christine is 31 years old and married with five children aged 18 – 7 months. She also cares for an orphan in primary school. She sells her clothes from various locations and her dream is to build her own shop and trade from there. She needs a loan to help buy more stock for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to increase her stock

loans.name: Pape Moussa

texts.fr: Monsieur Pape Moussa D. est un jeune homme Sénégalais qui sollicite un crédit pour continuer la construction de sa maison.  Monsieur D. a déjà reçu deux crédits qu’il a utilisés pour construire les murs et la toiture de sa maison, et il les a bien remboursés.  Avec ce troisième crédit, il veut mettre en place les portes et finir la maison.  Monsieur D. est marié et il a deux enfants, un fils et une fille.  Ils ont déménagé de Dakar à Mbour, une ville située à 70 kilomètres de la capitale, et il travaille dur pour bien soutenir sa famille dans leur nouveau milieu avec l’aide de l’IMCEC et Kiva.  Il est employé à la station d’essence comme pompiste et il rembourse les prêts avec son salaire.
texts.en:
Mr. Pape Moussa D. is a young Senegalese man who is requesting a loan to continue building his house. He has already received two loans, which he used to build the walls and the roof, and he has repaid them. With this third loan, he wants to install the doors and to finish the house. Mr. D. is married and has two children, a son and a daughter. They moved from Dakar to Mbour, a city located 70 km from the capital. And he works hard to take care of his family well, there in their new place, with the help of IMCEC and Kiva. He is employed at the gas station as a pump attendant. He repays the loans with his salary.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build his house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To sell staple goods

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is 37 years old and married with four children. He makes laundry detergent to sell. He is requesting for the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more laundry detergent materials. He says thanks to kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more laundry detergent materials

loans.name: Femmes Commeràçante 4 Group

texts.fr: Les 5 femmes membres du groupes sont unis par le bon voisinage depuis longtemps. Elles sont dans un groupe fédéral de toutes les femmes de la commune de Thiès. C'est le groupement qui a été subdivisé en groupe de 5 pour faciliter la gestion. Les groupes sont créés par affinité par les femmes elles-mêmes. Elles mènent diverses activités génératrices de revenus et soutiennent leurs maris dans la prise en charges de leur famille respective. Le groupe s'autofinançait par une tontine interne mais avec le crédit de l'IMCEC il trouve des moyens plus importants et un délais court pour le financement de leurs activités.
texts.en:
The five women members of the group have been united for a long time by a good neighborhood. They are in a federal group of all the women in the community of Thiès. It's an association that is subdivided into groups of five in order to facilitate the managing of it. The groups are created by affinity among the women themselves. These group members do a diversity of income-generating work and support their husbands in providing for their respective families. The group used to finance themselves through an internal tontine (a traditional community revolving savings and loan group), but with the loan from IMCEC, greater funding along with shorter term lengths may be gotten for their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy local goods in the weekly rural markets and fishing areas to be resold in town

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en:
Kanonya Margaret is the leader of Kuteesa group in Lugazi. She is 47 and is a devoted and determined married lady. She is the mother six children aged 30–14 years old and five of which are still in school. She also helps to cater to four orphans with the help of her husband and this has given her the satisfaction that she can never rate. 

Margaret sells eggs from her poultry farm and has a bakery where she makes cakes and other simple confectioneries, as well as sells charcoal. She has spent ten years managing her businesses. One tool to her success is the quality of products for her customers. Margaret has a dream of expanding her businesses and keeping her family healthy and educated, as well as having more money to run her family and businesses. With her share of the loan, Margaret will buy more layer chicks that will give her more eggs to sell.

loans.use: Buying more layer chicks for increased egg production.

loans.name: Asror

texts.ru:
Асрор  Исроилов  таксист, но это не основной источник дохода в его семье, кроме этого он занимается сельским хозяйством, и животноводством. Дома у Асрора 7 голов крупнорогатого скота, откормом и перепродажей которых он занимается. Это и есть основной и главный источник его дохода. Асрор женат, у него 3 детей, которых надо содержать. Жена Асрора домохозяйка и занимается воспитанием детей. Благодаря своему трудолюбию Асрору удается успевать работать и на поле (выращивать сельхозкультуры), и дома (откармливать скот), и подрабатывать таксистом (развозить пассажиров по месту требования).
Он запрашивает займ в размере 500 сомони и хочет потратить его на закуп корма для своего скота.
texts.en:
Asror I. is a taxi driver, but that is not the main source of his family's income. In addition, he farms and raises livestock. At home, Asror has seven head of large-horned cattle, which he fattens and resells, and that is his main source of income. Asror is married, and has three children whom he needs to support. His spouse is a housewife and cares for the children. Thanks to his diligence, Asror has succeeded in working in the fields growing crops, at home raising cattle, and earning additional income as a taxi driver transporting passengers locally. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 500 somoni to spend on the purchase of cattle feed.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle feed

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita P. is from the village of Solano,Nueva Vizcaya. Juanita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Juanita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. 

Juanita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juanita is requesting a new loan, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is 38 years old and married with 5 children. She makes garri, which is gotten from cassava. She is requesting a loan to purchase more cassava to process into garri. She says thanks to kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava to process into garri to sell

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo A. is 32 years old and married without a child. She sells medicines and provisions. She is requesting for the loan amount of N40, 000 to purchase more medicines and provisions to sell. She says thanks to kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and medicines to sell

loans.name: Elza

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 44 years old Eliza M. from Mbeya. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 18 and 23. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant who is an orphan.

Eliza has been running a poultry business since 2005. Eliza keeps and sells chickens, working at the business for 1-4 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Eliza currently earns about 90 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to increase number of chickens in her project. In the future, she plans to move the business to a new location. Eliza thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To increase number of chickens in her project

loans.name: Ephrance's Group

texts.en: K. Ephrance, age 52, is the leader of Kuteesa group in Lugazi. She is a married lady with nine children, four of which are still in school while the rest are business people with their own families. She also has two orphans in her care. She is in the business of selling used clothings and charcoal. For the used clothing, she moves from place to place selling her clothes especially from daily markets. However, she sells the charcoal from her home in Luleeka, Lugazi. She has a plan of one day opening up a shop selling the same clothes instead of hawking. She also dreams of   educating her children at the University level. Ephrance needs a loan to help her buy more clothes to expand her stock so as to attract more customers.

loans.use: Buying more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia K. is married, and has three children. She attended school all the way through her Senior year. Cecilia works as a groceries and soft drinks vender, and also specializes in construction items such as cement and slate. She operates her business near Cape Coast, and has done so since 2000. Her husband is employed as a contractor. Cecilia uses her income to pay for the family rent, her children’s school fees, as well as the purchasing of restocking supplies such as soft drink and more groceries.

Cecilia is now requesting a loan in order to expand her business, and continue to support her family.

loans.use: To restock her inventory

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes 5 Group

texts.fr: Les 5 femmes membres du groupe sont unies par le bon voisinage depuis longtemps. Elles sont dans un groupe fédéral de toutes les femmes de la commune de Thiès. C'est le groupement qui a été subdivisé en groupe de 5 pour faciliter la gestion. Les groupes sont créés par affinité par les femmes elles-mêmes. Elles mènent diverses activités génératrices de revenus et soutiennent leurs maris dans la prise en charges de leur famille respective. Le groupe s'autofinançait par une tontine interne mais avec le crédit de l'IMCEC il trouve des moyens plus importants et un délai court pour le financement de leurs activités. La plupart d’entre elles ont des étalages au marché central de Thiès commune ou elles vendent légumes, poisson, bijoux, tissus, etc.
texts.en:
The five women members of the group have been united for a long time by a good neighborhood. They are in a federal group of all the women in the community of Thiès. It's an association subdivided into groups of five in order to facilitate the managing of it. The groups are created by affinity among the women themselves. The women do a diversity of income-generating work and support their husbands in providing for their respective families. The group used to finance itself through an internal tontine (a traditional community revolving savings and loan group), but with the loan from IMCEC, greater funding along with shorter terms may be gotten for their businesses. Most of the group members have a display of goods at the central market of Thiès, where they sell vegetables, fish, jewelry, cloth, etc.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy local products in the weekly rural marketplaces and fishing areas to be sold in town

loans.name: Aissatou

texts.fr: Madame Aissatou D. est une commerçante qui sollicite son premier crédit pour renforcer sa cantine.  Chaque matin et chaque soir, Madame D. prépare de la sauce et des haricots pour faire les sandwiches qu’elle vend au bord de la route dans son quartier.  Son entreprise est située à coté d’une école primaire. Les élèves mangent chez elle pour le petit déjeuner, le déjeuner, et les goutées.  Elle a fait cette activité depuis trois ans et elle n’a jamais sollicité un prêt.  Cependant, elle est tombée malade et elle a arrêté le travail pendant un peu de temps.  Alors, pour redémarrer son activité, elle voudrait un prêt avec lequel elle va acheter tout les ingrédients dont elle a besoin.  Elle est mariée, et elle a commencé cette entreprise pour aider dans les dépenses familiales.   Elle habite à Mbour, une ville située à 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale du Sénégal.
texts.en:
Ms. Aissatou D. is a merchant who is requesting her first loan to bolster her cantine. Each morning and evening, she makes some sauce and beans to make the sandwiches that she sells on the roadside in her area. Her enterprise is located next to the primary school. The children have breakfast, lunch, and after-school snacks at her stall. She has been in this business for three years has never sought a loan. However, she fell ill and halted work for awhile. So, to start up again, she would like a loan, with which she will buy all the ingredients she needs. She is married, and she started this enterprise to help cover family expenses. She lives in Mbour, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goods for her cantine

loans.name: Gladness

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40 year old Gladness N. from Dares Salaam. She is married with three children, between the ages of 10 and 17. Gladness has been running a café business since 2000. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week. Gladness currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase ingredients in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Gladness thanks you for your support!
	
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her Cafe

loans.name: Emelia Kapange

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 37 year old Emelia K. from Tukuyu. Emelia is married with one child, under the age of one. Emelia has been running a corps business since 2000. 

Emelia's business is purchasing and selling crops. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. and currently earns about 90 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase crops in bulk. In the future, she hopes to open a new business. Emelia thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John M. works as a driver and a mechanic at Moree near Cape Coast, which he has done since 2003. He is married with eight dependents and has received an education through senior high school. While John works as a driver, his wife makes her living as a fishmonger. He is responsible for paying for utilities, food, and his children’s school fees.

John’s loan will be used to purchase an engine for his car and he hopes to use the new profits from his business to expand his enterprise.

loans.use: To purchase an engine for his car

loans.name: Mwajuma's Group

texts.en:
N. Mwajuma, 34, is the leader of Kweyamba group in Lugazi. She is a married lady with four children aged 15 – 7 years. She also cares for other orphans.

Mwajuma is a hardworking lady who has run her business for fifteen years. Yet she still has a dream of expanding her business more, educating her children, buying more plots of land, and so on. 

Mwajuma has been able to pay back her loan on time and, this time round, she needs a new loan to be able to buy more soft drinks to increase her stock. With the loan, she will buy more sodas, mineral water and juice from the factories for her employees to sell.

loans.use: To buy sodas, mineral water and juice to increase her stock

loans.name: Bassem

texts.en:
Bassem is a 32-year-old man who lives in Tyre, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Bassem repairs and sells air conditioners. He has requested a loan of $1000 USD from Al Majmoua to purchase air conditioners. This is the first time that Bassem has requested a loan.

Bassem is distinguished in his work because he does it well. Bassem chose his business because he wanted to work independently. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Bassem will use the loan to purchase air conditioners.

loans.name: Mor

texts.fr: Monsieur Mor D. est un jeune homme marié qui est plombier.  Il sollicite son deuxième crédit auprès de l’IMCEC pour acheter des outils dont il a besoin pour mieux faire son travail.  Il a déjà reçu un crédit de 100,000 CFA ($200) et il l’a bien remboursé sans les délais.  Quand il était jeune, Monsieur D. a laissé ses études après six ans.  Apres avoir quitté l’école, il devait chercher une profession.  Il avait une connaissance qui travaillait comme plombier, donc il a commencé à travailler avec lui pour apprendre le métier.  Au fur et a mesure, il a maitrisé le travail et il a ouvert son propre atelier.  Il a deux emploies qu’il forme, et il utilise les revenus de son entreprise pour soutenir sa famille et ses parents.  Il habite à Mbour, une ville située à 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale du Sénégal.
texts.en:
Mr. Mor D. is a young married man who is a plumber. He's requesting his second loan from IMCEC to buy some tools he needs for doing his work better. He has already received a loan of 100,000 francs CFA, and he repaid it without being late. When he was young he left school after six years. After leaving, he had to look for a profession. He had an acquaintance who used to work as a plumber, so he started working with him to learn this trade. By and by, he mastered the work, and he opened his own workshop. He has two positions that he's developing. And he's using the revenues from his enterprise to support his family and parents. He lives in Mbour, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plumber tools

loans.name: Florida

texts.en:
Florida is a 49-year-old married mother of four school-aged children, and is from the town of Cabatuan. To make a living, Florida has owned and operated a general store for over a year. The business' main source of income, although not the only one, comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community.

Florida joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florida is requesting a new loan from ASKI of 10 000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the extra revenue generated to improve and expand her business. She is determined to be successful, but has patience as well. She hopes to achieve her hopes and dreams some day.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines, committed to serving the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Fotima

texts.ru:
Мусоева Фотима, мать 5 детей, замужем.Дома она занимается животноводством, и стаж ее работы в этой сфере привышает 10 лет. Кроме этого, она вышивает тюбитейки . Это национальные головные уборы,  национальные платки. В этой нелегкой ручной работе ей помогает дочь, которую она обучила. Но это еще не все, Фотима выращивает дома несколько деревьев грецкого ореха, собирает грецкий орех,перерабатывает его и продает на рынке.
  Муж Фотимы занимается купле продажей стройматериалов на рынке, что приносит дополнительный доход в их семью.
 Фотима хочет получить займ 1600 сомони и использовать его для откорма своего скота.
texts.en:
Fotima M. is married and the mother of five children. She raises livestock at home and has more than ten years of work experience in that endeavor. In addition, she embroiders traditional Tajik scarves and headwear, tubeteika. She taught her daughter, who assists her with this difficult handwork. In addition, Fotima also has several walnut trees. She gathers the nuts, processes them, and sells them at the market. Fotima's husband buys and sells building materials in the market to bring in extra income for the family. Fotima would like to take out a loan in the amount of 1600 somoni to use for cattle feed.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle feed

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is from the village of Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old, and is married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn owns and operates a business selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling personal home products to tourists and members of the local community.

Marilyn joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan from ASKI of 8000 PHP, which she will use to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines, committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rabii

texts.en:
Rabii is a 32-year-old man who lives in Tyre, in Southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Rabii has been working as a blacksmith. He has requested a loan of $1500 USD from Al Majmoua to purchase iron. This is his second loan and he has always paid on time.

His previous loan helped him to improve his business. Rabii chose his business because he wanted to work independently. In the future, he plans to improve his business.

loans.use: Rabii will use the loan to purchase iron.

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf femmes du groupe  Soutoura sont toutes mariées avec en moyenne  38 ans et  5 enfants. Elles vivent majoritairement dans des familles monogames à Sanoubougou I,  un des  quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  3ème région administrative de la république du Mali.
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de savons,  des fruits, des pagnes wax et des céréales.
Elles sont à leur  troisième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but  de  satisfaire le besoin de leurs  clientèles et d’augmenter leurs profits. Les  deux prêts précédents  se sont  bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter  60 cartons de savon, 15 colis de fruits, 15 pièces de pagnes wax, 200 kg de céréales. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, Bamako et dans les villages environnants. Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant, en détail et à crédit.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider les maris à subvenir aux dépenses familiales et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Soutoura  ambitionnent de devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
The nine women of the group Soutoura are all married and average 38 years of age and 5 children each. They live for the most part in monogamous families in Sanoubougou I, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do a diversity of work, including selling soap, fruit, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), and grains. The group members are on their third collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of satisfying customer needs and to increase their profits. The two preceding loans were settled. With this new loan, they intend to buy 60 boxes of soap, 15 packages of fruit, 15 bolts of Wax pagnes, and 200 kg of grain. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso, in Bamako, and in surrounding villages. The merchandise is sold at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City, locally at home, and door-to-door, to customers composed of women and men, cash or credit accepted. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 23,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used to help their husband cover family expenses, and the other portion will be invested in business and for repaying the loan. Their ambition is to become wholesale merchants.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Hicham

texts.en:
Hicham is a 33-year-old man who lives in Tyre, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their child. He has been working as a fisherman for eleven years. He fishes and then sells the fish to fish shops. Hicham requested a loan of $500 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a fishing net.

This is Hicham’s second loan and he has always paid on time. His previous loan helped him improve his business. His clients can be anybody. When he first started his work, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided to start his business because he wanted to have an independent job. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing net

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en: Houssein is a 27-year-old man who lives in Tyre in southern Lebanon. Houssein has been working as a blacksmith for 12 years. He requested a loan of $1,000 from Al Majmoua to purchase electrical wires for his work and repaid that on time. This is his third loan; he has always paid on time. Houssein started his business because he wanted to work independently, and the business quickly became successful. In the future, he plans on improving his business and honing his skills.

loans.use: Purchase of electrical wire

loans.name: Thekla

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 37 year old Thekla M. from Dar es Salaam. She is single with one child, who is 10 year s old. Thekla has been running a beauty salon business since 2007. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week. Thekla currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase hair steamer and hair product. In the future, she plans to open another business. Thekla thanks you for your support!
	
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase hair steamer and hair product.

loans.name: Emelia Mbilinyi

texts.en: Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Emelia M. from Mbeya. She is married with two children aged 5 and 11. Emelia has been running a fish business since 2008, purchasing and selling fish. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week. She currently earns about $50 a month from her business. Emelia is requesting a loan in order to purchase fish in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Emelia thanks you for your support! ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase fish in bulk for her business

loans.name: Hamidi

texts.en:
Hamidi is a 56 year old woman who lives in Tyre, Southern Lebanon with her husband and their two children. Hamidi owns a bakery shop. She makes bread, “saj” and “mankoucheh”.  “Saj” is also the name of the metal oven where the traditional Lebanese saj bread is cooked. The oven is also used to make Markouk (“thinned”) bread and doughy confections or Mankoucheh. A Mankoucheh--looks like a folded pizza--most commonly has toppings like zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese), and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it throughout the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. 

Hamidi needs 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials for her bakery. She has paid back her first loan on time and this is her second loan request. Her previous loan helped Hamidi improve her business. Hamidi's clients can be anybody. When she first started her work, she didn’t face difficulties. Hamidi decided to start her business because she wanted to have independence. In the future, she plans on improving her work.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her bakery.

loans.name: Bolokolognite Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Bolokolognitè est constitué de cinq  femmes (dont trois mariés et les deux autres  célibataires)  qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Mancourani I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3 ème région administrative de la république  du Mali. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de  tissus, pagnes wax, fruits,  bois de chauffe, produits de beauté etc.  
Collaborant avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et d’augmenter leur profit, elles sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les deux précédents.
 Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 3 chargements de charrettes en bois  de chauffe, 25 pièces de pagnes  wax, 6 régimes de bananes, 10 baignoires   de mangue, 10 complets de tissus pour  enfants et 15 colis de produits de beauté. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Bamako, de Médine à Sikasso ville et  dans les localités avoisinantes. Les marchandises sont vendues, la plupart au comptant., dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les familles à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Bolokolognitè ambitionnent de devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
The group Bolokolognitè is composed of five women (three who are married and two who are not). Most of them live in monogamous families in Mancourani I, a district of Sikasso City (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do a diversity of work, including selling fabrics, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), fruit, firewood, beauty products, etc. Collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy customer needs and to increase their profits, the group members are on their third solidarity loan, after having correctly repaid the preceding two. With this new loan, they intend to buy 3 cart-loads of firewood, 25 bolts of Wax pagnes, 6 bunches of bananas, 10 basins of mangoes, 10 outfits for children, and 15 packages of beauty products. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Bamako, from Médine in Sikasso City, and in neighboring towns. The merchandise is sold mostly in cash transactions at different marketplaces of Sikasso, within families, to customers composed of men and women. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used for family needs, and the other portion will be invested in business and for repaying the loan. Their ambition is to become wholesale merchants.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Hayssam

texts.en: Hayssam is a 43-year-old man who lives in Saida in southern Lebanon, where he lives with his wife and their four children. Hayssam sells fruits and vegetables. Hayssam has requested a loan of $800 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for resale in his business. Hayssam has been a microcredit client for ten years now and has always paid on time. His previous loan helped him improve his work by diversifying his products, which improved his financial situation. In the future, Hayssam hopes to continue improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for resale

loans.name: Joeliz

texts.en:
Joeliz is from the village of San Fermin. She is 35 years old and single. She owns and operates a business operating a specialized retail store, primarily selling fruits and vegetables in the market.

Joeliz joined ASKI (Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc.) to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.

Joeliz is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Joeliz from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

Joeliz diligently works at developing her business in order to support her family with their immediate needs, and also to support her younger brothers and sister in their education. She hopes to prosper in her vending business and become successful someday.


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en:
Khalil is 36 years old and lives in Saida, south Lebanon, with his wife and their five children. He has been selling used furniture for ten years and also works as a furniture mover.  Khalil's clients can be anyone.  Khalil has requested a loan of $2200 from A. Majmoua in order to do some maintenance on his truck and to purchase used furniture.  

Khalil has been a loan client for nine years now and has always paid on time.  His previous loan helped him improve his business as well as his financiA. situation.  When Khalil first started this business he had difficulty convincing people to purchase used furniture and his financiA. status was also less secure.  Khalil chose this business because he was convinced that it would succeed since not everyone can afford to buy new furniture.  In the future, Khalil hopes to expand his business by opening a warehouse.

loans.use: For maintenance work on his truck and to purchase used furniture

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 42-year-old man who lives in Saida in southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Ahmad has owned a pickup truck since 2003. He requested a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order do some maintenance work on his truck; he repaid that loan on time. This is his second requested loan.

Ahmad's clients can be people from his region and factories. When he first started with his business, he had some financial issues as well as difficulty networking. Ahmad decided on his line of work because he wants to improve his family’s income. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his truck

loans.name: Mouhamadou

texts.fr: Mouhamadou Touré est un jeune commerçant  qui s’active dans la vente de produits de mercerie dans un marché de la ville de Mbour située à 70km de la capitale sénégalaise Dakar. Il a 2 ans d’expériences dans le domaine du commerce dont 18 mois comme employer et depuis 6 mois il gère son propre magasin. Il n’a jamais eu de prêt. Les revenus tirés du commerce sont réinjecter pour renforcer le fonds de commerce. Avec le prêt qu’il sollicite  il compte  renforcer son activité en achetant plus de marchandises.
texts.en:
Mouhamadou Touré is a young merchant who is active in selling sewing supplies in a marketplace of the city of Mbour, located 70 km from the Senegalese capital, Dakar. He has two years of experience in the field of business, including 18 months as an employee, and for six months he managed his own store. He has never had a loan. The revenues derived from his business are re-injected to boost his working capital. With this loan he's requesting, he intends to bolster his business by buying more merchandise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes 15 Group

texts.fr: Les 5 femmes membres du groupe sont unies par le bon voisinage depuis longtemps. Elles sont dans un groupe fédéral de toutes les femmes de la commune de Thiès. C'est le groupement qui a été subdivisé en groupe de 5 pour faciliter la gestion. Les groupes sont créés par affinité par les femmes elles-mêmes. Elles mènent diverses activités génératrices de revenus et soutiennent leurs maris dans la prise en charges de leur famille respective. Le groupe s'autofinançait par une tontine interne mais avec le crédit de l'IMCEC il trouve des moyens plus importants et un délai court pour le financement de leurs activités. La plupart d’entre elles ont des étalages au marché central de Thiès commune ou elles vendent légumes, poisson, bijoux, tissus, etc.
texts.en:
The five women members of the group have been united for a long time by a good neighborhood. They are in a federal group of all the women in the community of Thiès. It's an association subdivided into groups of five in order to facilitate the managing of it. The groups are created by affinity among the women themselves, who do a diversity of income-generating work and who support their husbands in providing for their respective families. The group members used to finance themselves through an internal tontine (a traditional community revolving savings and loan group). But with IMCEC, they found greater funding in a short amount of time for their businesses. Most of the group members have a display of goods at the central market of Thiès, where they sell vegetables, fish, jewelry, cloth, etc.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy local goods in the weekly rural marketplaces and fishing areas to be sold in town

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick B. has been selling flour in Moree, near Cape Coast, since 2005. He also works as an artist and driver, while his wife is a seamstress. Patrick has received an education through to senior high school. He is responsible for paying the utility bills and feeding his family. Patrick will use his loan to buy an overlock machine and flour for resale. He hopes to use his new profits to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy an overlock machine and flour for resale
